thread.section_title: The Wall Street Journal & Breaking News, Business, Financial and Economic News, World News and Video
thread.title: Global Stock Rebound Continues in Asia

author: Gregor Stuart Hunter
title: Global Stock Rebound Continues in Asia
text:
0 COMMENTS Global stock markets were mixed Friday, with many recovering from declines a day earlier even as investors continued to weigh up the impact of higher inflation and interest rates on equities.
The Stoxx Europe 600 was roughly flat around noon in Europe, while most indexes in the Asia-Pacific region were higher.
Germany’s DAX and France’s CAC 40 rose 0.8% and 1.4% this week, respectively, but a 1.5% fall in Italy’s FTSE MIB weighed on the broader European index.
U.S. stocks were projected to open higher, with the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average futures contracts up 0.2% and 0.4%, respectively. On Thursday, U.S. stocks rose to pare the week’s losses .
As 10-year U.S. Treasury yields have ticked higher this year, equity investors are watching bond markets closely for signs that higher yields are affecting corporate performance.
“Historically, the probability of loss for the S&P 500 increases when the 10-year Treasury yield rises above 3%,” said Bank of America Merrill Lynch strategists in a research note this week.
In midday trading in Europe, U.S. 10-year Treasury yields dipped slightly from their levels Thursday, to 2.89%. That benchmark yield has risen from 2.4% at the end of 2017.
Boards displaying stock information at the Australian Securities Exchange in Sydney early this month. Photo: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg News Ten-year Treasury yields haven’t risen above 3% for four years, and even then yields only rose to such levels briefly.
“There’s been a generation of market participants that haven’t really seen a rising rate environment,” said Lyn Graham-Taylor, senior rates strategist at Rabobank.
“You’ve seen a lot of products and leverage, as has become clear in the past month, that has been built up by the hunt for yield and a long period of easy monetary policy,” he added.
The autos and parts sector of the Stoxx 600 was among the worst performing, falling 0.9%. Automotive supplier Valeo SA was among the worst performing stocks on the index, falling 11% after announcing a 2017 decline in net profit.
In European bond markets, German government bond yields continued to tick lower. 10-year bund yields fell to around 0.66%, from around 0.71% Thursday.
Solid stock gains were seen in many parts of Asia-Pacific. Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index was recently up 1%, and a gauge of Chinese companies with listings in the city climbed 2%.
Australia’s S&P/ASX 200 closed 0.8% higher to cap its best week since October, and a 1.5% rise gave South Korea’s Kospi its best day since Oct. 10.
China’s Shenzen A-Share index was up 0.2%.
“Asia is in a good position to ride out interest-rates hikes from the Federal Reserve given the prospects of a weaker dollar and a solid outlook for Asian exports,” said Christy Tan, head of markets strategy/research for Asia at National Australia Bank .
In foreign exchange markets, the greenback strengthened slightly, with the WSJ Dollar Index up 0.1%.
Oil prices sipped slightly, with Brent crude down 0.5% to $66.06 a barrel, and WTI down 0.4% to $62.50 a barrel.
Write to Mike Bird at Mike.Bird@wsj.com
